messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Metaheuristic conditional neural network for harvesting skyrmionic metastable states

Paper Abstract: Abstract We present a metaheuristic conditional neural-network-based method aimed at identifying physically interesting metastable states in a potential energy surface of high rugosity. To demonstrate how this method works, we identify and analyze spin textures with topological charge QùëÑQ ranging from 1 to ‚àí1313-13 (where antiskyrmions have Q<0ùëÑ0Q<0) in the Pd/Fe/Ir(111) system, which we model using a classical atomistic spin Hamiltonian based on parameters computed from density functional theory. To facilitate the harvest of relevant spin textures, we make use of the newly developed Segment Anything Model (SAM). Spin textures with QùëÑQ ranging from ‚àí33-3 to ‚àí66-6 are further analyzed using finite-temperature spin-dynamics simulations. We observe that for temperatures up to around 20 K, lifetimes longer than 200 ps are predicted, and that when these textures decay, new topological spin textures are formed. We also find that the relative stability of the spin textures depend linearly on the topological charge, but only when comparing the most stable antiskyrmions for each topological charge. In general, the number of holes (i.e., non-self-intersecting curves that define closed domain walls in the structure) in the spin texture is an important predictor of stability ‚Äì the more holes, the less stable is the texture. Methods for systematic identification and characterization of complex metastable skyrmionic textures ‚Äì such as the one demonstrated here ‚Äì are highly relevant for advancements in the field of topological spintronics.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Advances in protein structure prediction and design",
        "Machine learning for alloys",
        "Lifetime of racetrack skyrmions",
        "Structure prediction drives materials discovery",
        "Stabilizing spin spirals and isolated skyrmions at low magnetic field exploiting vanishing magnetic anisotropy",
        "Isolated zero field sub-10 nm skyrmions in ultrathin co films",
        "Interplay between topological and thermodynamic stability in a metastable magnetic skyrmion lattice",
        "Skyrmion formation in a bulk chiral magnet at zero magnetic field and above room temperature",
        "Two-dimensional skyrmion bags in liquid crystals and ferromagnets",
        "Magnetic skyrmion bundles and their current-driven dynamics",
        "Real-space observation of skyrmionium in a ferromagnet-magnetic topological insulator heterostructure",
        "Controlled creation and stability of k‚ÄãœÄùëòùúãk\\pi skyrmions on a discrete lattice",
        "Electrical manipulation of skyrmions in a chiral magnet",
        "Chiral magnetic skyrmions with arbitrary topological charge",
        "Beyond skyrmions: Review and perspectives of alternative magnetic quasiparticles",
        "Skyrmion-based artificial synapses for neuromorphic computing",
        "Topology dependence of skyrmion seebeck and skyrmion nernst effect",
        "Magnetic skyrmions, chiral kinks, and holomorphic functions",
        "Skyrmion dynamics in a frustrated ferromagnetic film and current-induced helicity locking-unlocking transition",
        "Multiply periodic states and isolated skyrmions in an anisotropic frustrated magnet",
        "Formation and stability of metastable skyrmionic spin structures with various topologies in an ultrathin film",
        "Complex magnetic textures in Ni/irn/Pt‚Äã(111)NisubscriptirùëõPt111\\mathrm{Ni}/{\\mathrm{ir}}_{n}/\\mathrm{Pt}(111) ultrathin films",
        "Writing and deleting single magnetic skyrmions",
        "Decoupled weight decay regularization",
        "Pytorch: An imperative style, high-performance deep learning library",
        "A method for atomistic spin dynamics simulations: implementation and examples",
        "Atomistic spin dynamics: Foundations and applications",
        "Searching magnetic states using an unsupervised machine learning algorithm with the heisenberg model",
        "Segment anything",
        "First-principles linear muffin-tin orbital atomic-sphere approximation calculations in real space",
        "First-principles real-space linear-muffin-tin-orbital calculations of 3d impurities in cu",
        "A local exchange-correlation potential for the spin polarized case. i",
        "Band filling effects on the emergence of magnetic skyrmions: Pd/fe and pd/co bilayers on ir(111)",
        "Zero-field skyrmionic states and in-field edge-skyrmions induced by boundary tuning",
        "How to reveal metastable skyrmionic spin structures by spin-polarized scanning tunneling microscopy",
        "Gilbert damping in magnetic layered systems",
        "Finite-temperature magnetism of fex‚Äãpd1‚àíxsubscriptfeùë•subscriptpd1ùë•{\\text{fe}}_{x}{\\text{pd}}_{1-x} and cox‚Äãpt1‚àíxsubscriptcoùë•subscriptpt1ùë•{\\text{co}}_{x}{\\text{pt}}_{1-x} alloys",
        "Definition and statistical distributions of a topological number in the lattice O(3) œÉùúé\\sigma-model",
        "Stable and fast semi-implicit integration of the stochastic landau‚Äìlifshitz equation",
        "Skyrmions with attractive interactions in an ultrathin magnetic film",
        "Asymmetric skyrmion-antiskyrmion production in ultrathin ferromagnetic films",
        "Role of higher-order exchange interactions for skyrmion stability",
        "Trends of higher-order exchange interactions in transition metal trilayers",
        "Method for finding mechanism and activation energy of magnetic transitions, applied to skyrmion and antivortex annihilation",
        "Enhanced skyrmion stability due to exchange frustration",
        "Local spin density functional approach to the theory of exchange interactions in ferromagnetic metals and alloys"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Metaheuristic conditional neural network for harvesting skyrmionic metastable states, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
